abstract.p: Ellen J Franck letter suggests that social workers try harder to help birth fathers become real parents, as alternative to foster care (S)

block.p: Re ''When the Foster Care System Forgets Fathers'' (front page, May 4): Although perceptions are shifting, the roles of fathers as breadwinners and mothers as caregivers still predominate. Research in child welfare has described birth fathers as ''ignored,'' ''forgotten'' and ''neglected.''

Foster care caseworkers often say that birth fathers make poor prospects as discharge options for their children. It is true that many birth fathers have inadequate parental skills, problems with substance abuse, and poor job histories. But so do many birth mothers with whom caseworkers work long and hard toward regaining custody of their children.

Re ''When the Foster Care System Forgets Fathers'' (front page, May 4): Although perceptions are shifting, the roles of fathers as breadwinners and mothers as caregivers still predominate. Research in child welfare has described birth fathers as ''ignored,'' ''forgotten'' and ''neglected.''

Foster care caseworkers often say that birth fathers make poor prospects as discharge options for their children. It is true that many birth fathers have inadequate parental skills, problems with substance abuse, and poor job histories. But so do many birth mothers with whom caseworkers work long and hard toward regaining custody of their children.
If these same efforts were focused on and tailored to birth fathers, this valuable resource for children in need of families would not be wasted.
ELLEN J. FRANCK Sea Cliff, N.Y., May 5, 2000
The writer is a social worker.
